elements.name: Stay-Cycle Micro-Review Pulse
elements.problem_it_solves: Replaces the impossible task of compressing 90 days into a single retrospective form with a one-tap weekly pulse that captures impressions at the moment of peak recall.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No competitor has per-stay-cycle review capture because OTAs have no concept of stay cycles within a lease -- their data model treats every booking as an atomic event with one review opportunity, while Split Lease's Stays Manager creates 13+ natural touchpoints per lease.
elements.description: A compact card that appears at the bottom of the Stays Manager after each weekly stay is marked complete. It shows the stay dates, asks a single sentiment question ('How was this stay?') via three emoji-free tap targets (Great / Fine / Rough), and optionally expands for a one-line note. The card is non-blocking -- the guest can dismiss it and return later. Over 13+ stays, these micro-pulses accumulate into a rich temporal review narrative visible on the guest's review timeline.

before_after.before: Booking.com: Zero review capture during a 90-day stay. One post-checkout email triggers a 7-subcategory retrospective form. The guest must compress months of experience into a single session from faded memory.
before_after.after: Split Lease: After each weekly stay, a gentle one-tap pulse appears in the Stays Manager the guest already visits. elements.name: Stay-Cycle Review Timeline
elements.problem_it_solves: Transforms accumulated micro-review pulses into a visible temporal narrative that rewards the reviewer with a sense of growing contribution and gives future guests a chronological view of the stay experience no competitor offers.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No competitor structures reviews around the chronological phases of a stay because they treat every booking as a single atomic event -- Split Lease is the only platform with per-stay-cycle data to render a temporal review narrative.
elements.description: A horizontal timeline visualization that appears both in the guest's own review history (Reward of the Self) and on the property listing for future guests (Reward of the Hunt). Each weekly stay is a node on the timeline showing the sentiment pulse (Great/Fine/Rough) with optional notes. The timeline reveals patterns over time: a property that starts 'Great' and stays 'Great' for 13 weeks tells a different story than one that dips to 'Rough' at week 6 when the heater broke. For the reviewer, seeing their pulses accumulate provides the Variable Reward that Booking.com's void-after-submission never delivers.

interaction_spec.animation: Nodes enter sequentially with 50ms stagger on page load; hover tooltip fades in 150ms; connecting line draws left-to-right on first view with 800ms duration
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, timeline becomes vertical with nodes stacked; scroll becomes vertical; notes appear inline below each node

before_after.before: Booking.com: A flat composite score (8.7) with no temporal dimension. A 3-month stay and a 2-night visit look identical. No way to see how the experience evolved over time, whether issues were resolved, or when problems occurred.
before_after.after: Split Lease: A visual timeline showing week-by-week sentiment across the entire lease. Future guests can see that the heater broke in week 6 but was fixed the next day -- a story that a flat score can never tell. The reviewer sees their contribution growing each week.

elements.name: Vetting Trust Shield
elements.problem_it_solves: Fills the trust desert for new and low-review listings by surfacing operational vetting data that Split Lease already collects -- employment verification, credit checks, landlord references -- as visible trust signals that function as pre-booking review equivalents.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No OTA performs deep vetting (employment, credit, landlord references) because their business model does not justify it for 2-night stays -- Split Lease already has this data as a core business process, making it a zero-cost trust signal that competitors cannot acquire without rebuilding their entire onboarding.
elements.description: A compact trust shield card that appears on every listing, replacing the empty review section for new properties with concrete operational data. It displays verification badges (ID verified, employment verified, credit checked), behavioral metrics from platform data (average host response time, lease renewal rate, guest completion rate), and vetting status for incoming guests. The card resolves the internal trigger of commitment anxiety ('Is this legit?') that Tag, Patricia, Michael, and Susan all expressed in transcripts, using data the platform already possesses.

elements.name: Priority Picker at Proposal
elements.problem_it_solves: Seeds the review habit at the moment of highest commitment by capturing what matters most to the guest, creating a personalized scaffold that transforms the post-lease review from a generic hotel form into a guided reflection the guest primed themselves for.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No platform uses the booking commitment moment to seed review expectations because OTA booking funnels are terrified of adding any friction -- Split Lease's multi-step proposal flow already has natural pause points where an optional priority question adds negligible friction while loading the next trigger per Eyal's Investment chapter.
elements.description: An optional priority selector that appears at the bottom of the proposal confirmation screen. It presents 8 long-term-housing-native quality dimensions as selectable chips and asks the guest to pick their top 3. These selections are stored and later used to scaffold micro-review prompts and the end-of-lease synthesis. The copy frames it as the platform caring about the guest's specific needs, not extracting data: 'Help us make sure this place works for you.'

elements.name: Trusted Reviewer Profile Card
elements.problem_it_solves: Creates the reviewer identity and visible impact that Booking.com's anonymous system completely lacks, transforming review contributions from disposable civic acts into accumulated reputation that delivers all three of Eyal's variable reward types: Tribe (social recognition), Hunt (impact metrics), and Self (trust tier achievement).
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No platform has built a reviewer identity system for housing because high-volume OTAs do not need individual reviewer retention -- their volume compensates for any reviewer's absence, while Split Lease's low-volume long-stay model makes every reviewer critical.
elements.description: A profile card that aggregates a user's review contributions across all their stays. It shows total reviews, total stays reviewed, the accumulated timeline of micro-review pulses, a trust tier badge ('Trusted Long-Stay Reviewer' after 2+ completed leases), and impact metrics ('Your reviews were read 234 times'). The card appears in the user's own dashboard (Self reward), is optionally visible to hosts considering their proposal (Tribe reward), and is linked from their published reviews on listings (Hunt reward -- others can see this reviewer's depth of experience).

elements.name: Passive Signal Dashboard Row
elements.problem_it_solves: Converts communication and behavioral data the platform already captures -- message response times, maintenance resolution speed, date change frequency, renewal rates -- into visible review-equivalent quality signals that generate trust without requiring anyone to write a single word.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No competitor synthesizes behavioral data into visible quality signals because OTAs' 2-night bookings generate too few data points for statistically meaningful behavioral scores -- Split Lease's multi-month leases with weekly stays generate hundreds of data points per tenancy.
elements.description: A horizontal row of behavioral metric cards that appears in two contexts: (1) on the listing page below traditional reviews, showing aggregated host behavioral data, and (2) on the host's own dashboard, showing their performance metrics. Each card displays a single behavioral signal with a clear label, the metric value, and a subtle data source indicator ('Based on 47 messages across 6 guests'). The metrics are operational facts, not opinions -- they supplement traditional reviews with verifiable behavioral evidence.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Based on real platform data, not opinions
do: Always show the data source and sample size
Round to meaningful ranges -- '~2 hours' not '1 hour 47 minutes'
Use neutral framing -- present facts, not judgments
dont: Never present a behavioral signal without sufficient data (minimum 3 guests, 10 messages)
Never show individual data points -- always aggregate across guests
Never surface negative signals without context (e.g., a slow response might mean the host was traveling)

The platform has this data in its database (message timestamps, booking patterns) but never surfaces it. The guest's review must reconstruct these from memory. Tammy's same-day maintenance resolution and Kris's repeat-guest discounts are invisible to future guests.

Maintenance Speed: < 24 hrs. 75% renewal rate.' These are not opinions -- they are operational facts that generate trust automatically. The host's responsiveness reviews itself.

elements.name: End-of-Lease Review Synthesis Modal
elements.problem_it_solves: Replaces the cold-start retrospective review form with a synthesis of signals already captured, presenting the guest's own micro-review pulses and priority evaluations back to them for confirmation and optional elaboration -- transforming the review from a 15-minute cognitive exercise into a 2-minute reflection that feels like closing a chapter, not filling out a tax form.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No competitor can build a synthesis review because they have no mid-stay data to synthesize -- they must start from scratch at checkout, while Split Lease's accumulated micro-pulses, priority ratings, and passive signals provide a rich foundation that the guest merely confirms.
elements.description: A full-screen modal that appears when the guest's lease ends. It presents: (1) their stay journey timeline with all micro-pulses visualized, (2) their stated priorities from proposal time with current ratings pre-filled from pulse data, (3) a single open text prompt for anything they want to add, and (4) an impact preview showing how their review will appear to future guests. The modal celebrates the completion ('13 weeks reviewed -- thank you') and shows the guest their Reviewer Profile card updated with this contribution. The Variable Reward is immediate and multi-dimensional: Tribe (your review joins the community), Hunt (your priorities are now scored), Self (your timeline is complete).

before_after.before: Booking.com: 24-48 hours after checkout, an email arrives linking to a blank 7-subcategory form. The guest must recall 90 days, evaluate 7 dimensions, write two text blocks, and submit into a void. 'Thank you for your review.' No celebration, no impact preview, no acknowledgment that what they just did mattered.
before_after.after: Split Lease: At lease end, a modal shows the guest their own story: 13 dots on a timeline, 3 priorities already scored from their weekly pulses, and a single optional text box. The guest confirms what the platform already captured, adds a final note if they wish, and publishes into a celebration that shows exactly how their contribution helps the next person. Two minutes, not fifteen.
